title: PHPdate_create()Function

metadata.description: Learn about PHPdate_create()Function with clear explanations and practical examples.

content_sections.title: Details
content_sections.content:
Example
Return a new DateTime object, and then format the date:
<?php
$date=date_create("2013-03-15");
echo date_format($date,"Y/m/d");
?>

More examples at the bottom of this page.
Definition and Usage
The date_create() function returns a new DateTime object.
Syntax
date_create(
time, timezone)
Parameter Values
Parameter
Description
time
Optional. Specifies a date/time string. NULL indicates the current time
timezone
Optional. Specifies the timezone of
time
. Default is the current timezone.
Tip:
Look at a list of all supported timezones in PHP
Technical Details
Return Value:
Returns a new DateTime object on success. FALSE/Exception on failure
PHP Version:
5.2+
PHP Changelog:
PHP 
  7.1: Microseconds is now filled with actual value, not just "00000".
PHP 5.3: 
  An exception is thrown if
time
is an invalid 
  value. 
More Examples
Example
Return a new DateTime object (with a given timezone), and then format the date 
and time:
<?php
$date=date_create("2013-03-15 23:40:00",timezone_open("Europe/Oslo"));
echo date_format($date,"Y/m/d H:iP");
?>

★
+1

related_topics.title: C Common Pitfalls and How to Avoid Them

quiz.question: What is Default?
quiz.explanation: The correct definition of Default is 'the current timezone'.

quiz.question: What is Microseconds?
quiz.explanation: The correct definition of Microseconds is 'now filled with actual value'.

summary: This tutorial covers PHPdate_create()Function concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use PHPdate_create()Function effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of PHPdate_create()Function and how to apply it in your projects.
